ygData.subject: Re: Trouble running Fortran - Cantera interface
ygData.msgSnippet: David, Thank you for the response.  I believe I found all the settings you are referring to. 1.  Fortran project C-style argument passing: Under the Fortran

From: "killakella2000" <ryankel@...>
Subject: Re: Trouble running Fortran - Cantera interface
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=222852018; y=SnPP2CSW1mykJOEoctULoykNInwKGxJVjWLOK0ajezHkuUqlm7eYm4I
X-Yahoo-Profile: killakella2000

David,

Thank you for the response.  I believe I found all the settings you 
are referring to.  

1.  Fortran project "C-style" argument passing:
Under the Fortran project properties -> Fortran -> External 
Procedures, there is an option for "calling convention" with choices 
of DEFAULT, C-REFERENCE, STDCALL-REFERENCE, STDCALL, and CVF.  Is C-
REFERENCE the correct choice?  Aren't C functions pass-by-value?

2.  Option to generate lowercase names with trailing underscore:
Under the Fortran project properties -> Fortran -> External 
Procedures, there is an option for "Append Underscore to External 
Names" which I changed to "Yes".  This should be good-to-go.

3.  Link to Multithreaded DLL C Libraries:
This one seems a bit tricky.  Under the C++ project properties -> 
C/C++ -> Code Generation, there is an option for selecting the 
Runtime Library.  There is Multi-threaded, Multi-threaded Debug, 
Multi-threaded DLL, Single-threaded, and Single-threaded Debug.  
Also, under the Fortran project properties -> Fortran -> Libraries 
there are options to select the Runtime Library with similar 
options.  I found a good website describing these options at 
http://h18009.www1.hp.com/fortran/docs/vf-html/pg/pgwvfvc.htm.  When 
looking over this website, I wasn't sure which options to choose as 
far as static or dll and whether to use C debug libraries.  Any idea 
what the proper combination of Fortran and C runtime libraries are?  

Changing the "trailing underscore" option seems to really have 
opened something up, but unfortunately it is creating even more 
errors.  I will play around with these other options more, I was 
just hoping for some feedback from some superior programmers on 
these options.  

Thanks again,
Ryan


--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "Dave Goodwin" <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
> It looks to me like you need to change some of the default 
settings of the Fortran project. 
> Cantera is configured to use C-style argument passing, and the 
appropriate options need 
> to be selected for the Fortran project.  Also, set the compiler 
option to generate 
> lowercase names with a trailing underscore (like unix Fortran 
compilers do).  And finally, 
> link to the multithreaded DLL C libraries.  Without an Intel 
Fortran compiler myself, it is 
> hard to provide more detailed help, but hopefully this will take 
care of the problem. 
> 
> 
> --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "killakella2000" <ryankel@h...> 
wrote:
> > I thought I would repost this because I am still in need of some 
> > help.  I am still at the same point in trying to link the 
Fortran

two 
> > projects.  I would really appreciate any comments that might 
point 
> > me in the right direction for fixing these errors and getting 
the 
> > fortran-C++ interface to work with Cantera.  Thank you.
> > 
> > 
> >

compilers
> > > > (g++,

> > > >> C++) with Cantera should at least consider getting a 
machine 
> > that
> > > > runs
> > > >> some unix-like operating system, such as linux or Mac OS 
X.  You
> > > > can
> > > >> get one for less than $1K, and don't need to buy expensive
> > > > commercial
> > > >> compilers.  Just a thought...
> > > >>
> > > >> Dave G.
> > > >>
